SPEECH.LINE: The deerest friend to me, the kindest man,
The best condition’d, and vnwearied ſpirit
In doing curtesies: and one in whom
The ancient Romane honour more appeares
Then any that drawes breath in Italie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: What ſumme owes he the Iew?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: For me three thousand ducats.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: What, no more? Pay him ſixe thousand, and deface the bond: Double ſixe thousand, and then treble that, Before a friend of this description Shall lose a haire through Baſſanio's fault. First goe with me to Church, and call me wife, And then away to Venice to your friend: For neuer ſhall you lie by Portias ſide With an vnquiet ſoule. You ſhall haue gold To pay the petty debt twenty times ouer. When it is payd, bring your true friend along, My maid Nerriſſa, and my ſelfe meane time Will liue as maids and widdowes; come away, For you ſhall hence vpon your wedding day: Bid your friends welcome, ſhow a merry cheere, Since you are deere bought, I will loue you deere. But let me heare the letter of your friend. Sweet Baſſanio, my ſhips haue all miscarried, my Credi-tors grow cruell, my estate is very low, my bond to the Iew is forfeit, and ſince in paying it, it is impoſſible I ſhould liue, all debts are cleerd between you and I, if I might ſee you at my death: notwithstanding, vse your pleasure, if your loue doe not perswade you to come, let not my letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: O loue! dispach all busines and be gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Since I haue your good leaue to goe away, I will make hast; but till I come againe, No bed ſhall ere be guilty of my ſtay, Nor rest be interposer twixt vs twaine. Exeunt.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Iew, and Solanio, and Anthonio, and the Iaylor

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: Iaylor, looke to him, tell not me of mercy,
This is the foole that lends out money gratis.
Iaylor, looke to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Heare me yet good Shylok.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile haue my bond, ſpeake not against my bond,
I haue ſworne an oath that I will haue my bond:
Thou call’dst me dog before thou hadst a cause,
But ſince I am a dog, beware my phangs,
The Duke ſhall grant me iustice, I do wonder
Thou naughty Iaylor, that thou art ſo fond
To come abroad with him at his request.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray thee heare me ſpeake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile haue my bond, I will not heare thee ſpeake,
Ile haue my bond, and therefore ſpeake no more,
Ile not be made a ſoft and dull ey’d foole,
To ſhake the head, relent, and ſigh, and yeeld
To Christian interceſſors: follow not,
Ile haue no ſpeaking, I will haue my bond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: It is the mo’t impenetrable curre
That euer kept with men.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Let him alone,
Ile follow him no more with bootleſſe prayers:
He ſeekes my life, his reason well I know;
I oft deliuer’d from his forfeitures
Many that haue at times made mone to me,
Therefore he hates me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sol.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſure the Duke will neuer grant this forfeiture to hold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: The Duke cannot deny the course of law:
For the commoditie that ſtrangers haue
With vs in Venice, if it be denied,
Will much impeach the iustice of the State,
Since that the trade and profit of the citty
Consisteth of all Nations. Therefore goe,
These greefes and loſſes haue ſo bated mee,
That I ſhall hardly ſpare a pound of flesh
To morrow, to my bloudy Creditor.
Well Iaylor, on, pray God Baſſanio come
To ſee me pay his debt, and then I care not.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Portia, Nerriſſa, Lorenzo, Ieſſica, and a man of Portias

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, although I ſpeake it in your presence,
You haue a noble and a true conceit
Of god-like amity, which appeares mo’t ſtrongly
In bearing thus the absence of your Lord.
But if you knew to whom you ſhew this honour,
How true a Gentleman you ſend releefe,
How deere a louer of my Lord your husband,
I know you would be prouder of the worke
Then customary bounty can enforce you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: I neuer did repent for doing good,
Nor ſhall not now: for in companions
That do conuerse and waste the time together,
Whose ſoules doe beare an egal yoke of loue.
There must be needs a like proportion
Of lyniaments, of manners, and of ſpirit;
Which makes me thinke that this Anthonio
Being the bosome louer of my Lord,
Must needs be like my Lord. If it be ſo,
How little is the cost I haue bestowed
In purchasing the ſemblance of my ſoule;
From out the ſtate of hellish cruelty,
This comes too neere the praising of my ſelfe,
Therefore no more of it: heere other things
Lorenso I commit into your hands,
The husbandry and mannage of my house,
Vntill my Lords returne; for mine owne part
I haue toward heauen breath’d a ſecret vow,
To liue in prayer and contemplation,
Onely attended by Nerriſſa heere,
Vntill her husband and my Lords returne:
There is a monastery too miles off,
And there we will abide. I doe desire you
Not to denie this imposition,
The which my loue and ſome neceſſity
Now layes vpon you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lorens.
SPEECH.LINE: Madame, with all my heart,
I ſhall obey you in all faire commands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: My people doe already know my minde,
And will acknowledge you and Ieſſica
In place of Lord Baſſanio and my ſelfe.
So far you well till we ſhall meete againe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire thoughts & happy houres attend on you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ieſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: I wish your Ladiship all hearts content.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you for your wish, and am well pleas’d
To wish it backe on you: faryouwell Ieſſica.
Now Balthaser, as I haue euer found thee honeſt true,
So let me finde thee ſtill: take this ſame letter,
And vse thou all the indeauor of a man,
In ſpeed to Mantua, ſee thou render this
Into my cosins hand, Doctor Belario,
And looke what notes and garments he doth giue thee,
Bring them I pray thee with imagin’d ſpeed
Vnto the Tranect, to the common Ferrie
Which trades to Venice; waste no time in words,
But get thee gone, I ſhall be there before thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Balth.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, I goe with all conuenient ſpeed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Come on Neriſſa, I haue worke in hand
That you yet know not of; wee'll ſee our husbands
Before they thinke of vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nerriſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall they ſee vs?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Portia.
SPEECH.LINE: They ſhall Nerriſſa: but in ſuch a habit,
That they ſhall thinke we are accomplished
With that we lacke; Ile hold thee any wager
When we are both accoutered like yong men,
Ile proue the prettier fellow of the two,
And weare my dagger with the brauer grace,
And ſpeake betweene the change of man and boy,
With a reede voyce, and turne two minsing ſteps
Into a manly ſtride; and ſpeake of frayes
Like a fine bragging youth: and tell quaint lyes
How honourable Ladies ſought my loue,
Which I denying, they fell ſicke and died.
I could not doe withall: then Ile repent,
And wish for all that, that I had not kil’d them;
And twentie of these punie lies Ile tell,
That men ſhall ſweare I haue discontinued ſchoole
Aboue a twelue moneth: I haue within my minde
A thousand raw tricks of these bragging Iacks,
Which I will practise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nerris.
SPEECH.LINE: Why, ſhall wee turne to men?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Portia.
SPEECH.LINE: Fie, what a questions that?
If thou wert nere a lewd interpreter:
But come, Ile tell thee all my whole deuice
When I am in my coach, which ſtayes for vs
At the Parke gate; and therefore haste away,
For we must measure twentie miles to day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clown.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes truly; for looke you, the ſinnes of the Fa-ther are to be laid vpon the children, therefore I promise you, I feare you, I was alwaies plaine with you, and ſo now I ſpeake my agitation of the matter: therfore be of good cheere, for truly I thinke you are damn’d, there is but one hope in it that can doe you anie good, and that is but a kinde of bastard hope neither.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ieſſica.
SPEECH.LINE: And what hope is that I pray thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Marrie you may partlie hope that your father got you not, that you are not the Iewes daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ies.
SPEECH.LINE: That were a kinde of bastard hope indeed, ſo the ſins of my mother ſhould be visited vpon me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly then I feare you are damned both by fa-ther and mother: thus when I ſhun Scilla your father, I fall into Charibdis your mother; well, you are gone both waies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ies.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall be ſau’d by my husband, he hath made me a Christian.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Truly the more to blame he, we were Christi-ans enow before, e'ne as many as could wel liue one by a-nother: this making of Christians will raise the price of Hogs, if wee grow all to be porke-eaters, wee ſhall not ſhortlie haue a rasher on the coales for money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ies.
SPEECH.LINE: Ile tell my husband Lancelet what you ſay, heere he comes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall grow iealous of you ſhortly Lancelet, if you thus get my wife into corners?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ies.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, you need not feare vs Lorenzo, Launcelet and I are out, he tells me flatly there is no mercy for mee in heauen, because I am a Iewes daughter: and hee ſaies you are no good member of the common wealth, for in conuerting Iewes to Christians, you raise the price of Porke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſhall answere that better to the Common-wealth, than you can the getting vp of the Negrœs bel-lie: the Moore is with childe by you Launcelet?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: It is much that the Moore ſhould be more then reason: but if ſhe be leſſe then an honeſt woman, ſhee is indeed more then I tooke her for.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: How euerie foole can play vpon the word, I thinke the best grace of witte will ſhortly turne into ſi-lence, and discourse grow commendable in none onely but Parrats: goe in ſirra, bid them prepare for dinner?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: That is done ſir, they haue all ſtomacks?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: Goodly Lord, what a witte-snapper are you, then bid them prepare dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: That is done to ſir, onely couer is the word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: Will you couer than ſir?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: Not ſo ſir neither, I know my dutie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: Yet more quarreling with occasion, wilt thou ſhew the whole wealth of thy wit in an instant; I pray thee vnderstand a plaine man in his plaine meaning: goe to thy fellowes, bid them couer the table, ſerue in the meat, and we will come in to dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clow.
SPEECH.LINE: For the table ſir, it ſhall be ſeru’d in, for the meat ſir, it ſhall bee couered, for your comming in to dinner ſir, why let it be as humors and conceits ſhall go-uerne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: O deare discretion, how his words are ſuted,
The foole hath planted in his memory
An Armie of good words, and I doe know
A many fooles that ſtand in better place,
Garnisht like him, that for a tricksie word
Defie the matter: how cheer'st thou Ieſſica,
And now good ſweet ſay thy opinion,
How dost thou like the Lord Baſſiano's wife?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ieſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: Past all expreſſing, it is very meete
The Lord Baſſanio liue an vpright life
For hauing ſuch a bleſſing in his Lady,
He findes the ioyes of heauen heere on earth,
And if on earth he doe not meane it, it
Is reason he ſhould neuer come to heauen?
Why, if two gods ſhould play ſome heauenly match,
And on the wager lay two earthly women,
And Portia one: there must be ſomething else
Paund with the other, for the poore rude world
Hath not her fellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen ſuch a husband
Hast thou of me, as ſhe is for a wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ies.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but aske my opinion to of that?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: I will anone, first let vs goe to dinner?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ies.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, let me praise you while I haue a ſtomacke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: No pray thee, let it ſerue for table talke,
Then how ſom ere thou ſpeakst 'mong other things,
I ſhall digest it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ieſſi
SPEECH.LINE: Well, Ile ſet you forth.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter the Duke, the Magnificœs, Anthonio, Baſſanio, and Gratiano

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: What, is Anthonio heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Ready, ſo please your grace?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſorry for thee, thou art come to answere
A ſtonie aduersary, an inhumane wretch,
Vncapable of pitty, voyd, and empty
From any dram of mercie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue heard
Your Grace hath tane great paines to qualifie
His rigorous course: but ſince he ſtands obdurate,
And that no lawful meanes can carrie me
Out of his enuies reach, I do oppose
My patience to his fury, and am arm’d
To ſuffer with a quietneſſe of ſpirit,
The very tiranny and rage of his.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Go one and cal the Iew into the Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: He is ready at the doore, he comes my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Make roome, and let him ſtand before our face.
Shylocke the world thinkes, and I thinke ſo to
That thou but leadest this fashion of thy mallice
To the last houre of act, and then ‘tis thought
Thou'lt ſhew thy mercy and remorse more ſtrange,
Than is thy ſtrange apparant cruelty;
And where thou now exact'st the penalty,
Which is a pound of this poore Merchants flesh,
Thou wilt not onely loose the forfeiture,
But touch’d with humane gentleneſſe and loue:
Forgiue a moytie of the principall,
Glancing an eye of pitty on his loſſes
That haue of late ſo hudled on his backe,
Enow to preſſe a royall Merchant downe;
And plucke commiseration of his ſtate
From braſſie bosomes, and rough hearts of flints,
From ſtubborne Turkes and Tarters neuer traind
To offices of tender curtesie,
We all expect a gentle anſwer Iew?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue poſſest your grace of what I purpose,
And by our holy Sabbath haue I ſworne
To haue the due and forfeit of my bond.
If you denie it, let the danger light
Vpon your Charter, and your Cities freedome.
You'l aske me why I rather choose to haue
A weight of carrion flesh, then to receiue
Three thousand Ducats? Ile not anſwer that:
But ſay it is my humor; Is it answered?
What if my house be troubled with a Rat,
And I be pleas’d to giue ten thousand Ducates
To haue it bain’d? What, are you anſwer’d yet?
Some men there are loue not a gaping Pigge:
Some that are mad, if they behold a Cat:
And others, when the bag-pipe ſings i'th nose,
Cannot containe their Vrine for affection.
Masters of paſſion ſwayes it to the moode
Of what it likes or loaths, now for your anſwer:
As there is no firme reason to be rendred
Why he cannot abide a gaping Pigge?
Why he a harmleſſe neceſſarie Cat?
Why he a woollen bag-pipe: but of force
Must yeeld to ſuch ineuitable ſhame,
As to offend himselfe being offended:
So can I giue no reason, nor I will not,
More then a lodg’d hate, and a certaine loathing
I beare Anthonio, that I follow thus
A loosing ſuite against him? Are you answered?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: This is no anſwer thou vnfeeling man,
To excuse the currant of thy cruelty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: I am not bound to please thee with my anſwer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Do all men kil the things they do not loue?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: Hates any man the thing he would not kill?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Euerie offence is not a hate at first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: What wouldst thou haue a Serpent ſting thee twice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you thinke you question with the Iew:
You may as well go ſtand vpon the beach,
And bid the maine flood baite his vsuall height,
Or euen as well vse question with the Wolfe,
The Ewe bleate for the Lambe:
You may as well forbid the Mountaine Pines
To wagge their high tops, and to make no noise
When they are fretted with the gusts of heauen:
You may as well do any thing mo’t hard,
As ſeeke to ſoften that, then which what harder?
His Iewish heart. Therefore I do beseech you
Make no more offers, vse no farther meanes,
But with all briefe and plaine conueniencie
Let me haue iudgement, and the Iew his will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bas.
SPEECH.LINE: For thy three thousand Ducates heere is ſix.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: If euerie Ducat in ſixe thousand Ducates
Were in ſixe parts, and euery part a Ducate,
I would not draw them, I would haue my bond?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: How ſhalt thou hope for mercie, rendring none?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: What iudgement ſhall I dread doing no wrong?
You haue among you many a purchast ſlaue,
Which like your Aſſes, and your Dogs and Mules,
You vse in abiect and in ſlauish parts,
Because you bought them. Shall I ſay to you,
Let them be free, marrie them to your heires?
Why ſweate they vnder burthens? Let their beds
Be made as ſoft as yours: and let their pallats
Be ſeason’d with ſuch Viands: you will anſwer
The ſlaues are ours. So do I anſwer you.
The pound of flesh which I demand of him
Is deerely bought, ‘tis mine, and I will haue it.
If you deny me; fie vpon your Law,
There is no force in the decrees of Venice;
I ſtand for iudgement, anſwer, Shall I haue it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Vpon my power I may dismiſſe this Court,
Vnleſſe Bellario a learned Doctor,
Whom I haue ſent for to determine this,
Come heere to day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sal.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord, heere ſtayes without
A Meſſenger with Letters from the Doctor,
New come from Padua.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Bring vs the Letters, Call the Meſſengers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Good cheere Anthonio. What man, corage yet:
The Iew ſhall haue my flesh, blood, bones, and all,
Ere thou ſhalt loose for me one drop of blood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I am a tainted Weather of the flocke,
Meetest for death, the weakest kinde of fruite
Drops earliest to the ground, and ſo let me;
You cannot better be employ’d Baſſanio,
Then to liue ſtill, and write mine Epitaph.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Came you from Padua from Bellario?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ner.
SPEECH.LINE: From both.
My Lord Bellario greets your Grace.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bas.
SPEECH.LINE: Why dost thou whet thy knife ſo earnestly?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: To cut the forfeiture from that bankrout there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: Not on thy ſoale: but on thy ſoule harsh Iew
Thou mak'st thy knife keene: but no mettall can,
No, not the hangmans Axe beare halfe the keenneſſe
Of thy ſharpe enuy. Can no prayers pierce thee?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: No, none that thou hast wit enough to make.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: O be thou damn’d, inexecrable dogge,
And for thy life let iustice be accus’d:
Thou almost mak'st me wauer in my faith;
To hold opinion with Pythagoras,
That ſoules of Animals infuse themselues
Into the trunkes of men. Thy currish ſpirit
Gouern’d a Wolfe, who hang’d for humane ſlaughter,
Euen from the gallowes did his fell ſoule fleet;
And whil'st thou layest in thy vnhallowed dam,
Infus’d it ſelfe in thee: For thy desires
Are Woluish, bloody, ſteru’d, and rauenous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: Till thou canst raile the ſeale from off my bond
Thou but offend'st thy Lungs to ſpeake ſo loud:
Repaire thy wit good youth, or it will fall
To endleſſe ruine. I ſtand heere for Law.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: This Letter from Bellario doth commend
A yong and Learned Doctor in our Court;
Where is he?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ner.
SPEECH.LINE: He attendeth heere hard by
To know your anſwer, whether you'l admit him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: With all my heart. Some three or four of you Go giue him curteous conduct to this place, Meane time the Court ſhall heare Bellariœs Letter. Your Grace ſhall vnderstand, that at the receite of your Letter I am very ſicke: but in the instant that your mes-senger came, in louing visitation, was with me a yong Do-ctor of Rome, his name is Balthasar: I acquainted him with the cause in Controuersie, betweene the Iew and Anthonio the Merchant: We turn’d ore many Bookes together: hee is furnished with my opinion, which bettred with his owne lear-ning, the greatneſſe whereof I cannot enough commend, comes with him at my importunity, to fill vp your Graces request in my ſted. I beseech you, let his lacke of years be no impediment to let him lacke a reuerend estimation: for I neuer knewe ſo yong a body, with ſo old a head. I leaue him to your gracious acceptance, whose trial ſhall better publish his commendation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: You heare the learn’d Bellario what he writes,
And heere (I take it) is the Doctor come.
Giue me your hand: Came you from old Bellario?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: I did my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: You are welcome: take your place;
Are you acquainted with the difference
That holds this present question in the Court.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: I am enformed throughly of the cause.
Which is the Merchant heere? and which the Iew?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Anthonio and old Shylocke, both ſtand forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Is your name Shylocke?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: Shylocke is my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Of a ſtrange nature is the ſute you follow,
Yet in ſuch rule, that the Venetian Law
Cannot impugne you as you do proceed.
You ſtand within his danger, do you not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I, ſo he ſayes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Do you confeſſe the bond?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Then must the Iew be mercifull.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: On what compulsion must I ? Tell me that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: The quality of mercy is not ſtrain’d,
It droppeth as the gentle raine from heauen
Vpon the place beneath. It is twice blest,
It bleſſeth him that giues, and him that takes,
‘Tis mightiest in the mightiest, it becomes
The throned Monarch better then his Crowne.
His Scepter ſhewes the force of temporall power,
The attribute to awe and Maiestie,
Wherein doth ſit the dread and feare of Kings:
But mercy is aboue this ſceptred ſway,
It is enthroned in the hearts of Kings,
It is an attribute to God himselfe;
And earthly power doth then ſhew likest Gods
When mercie ſeasons Iustice. Therefore Iew,
Though Iustice be thy plea, consider this,
That in the course of Iustice, none of vs
Should ſee ſaluation: we do pray for mercie,
And that ſame prayer, doth teach vs all to render
The deeds of mercie. I haue ſpoke thus much
To mittigate the iustice of thy plea:
Which if thou follow, this ſtrict course of Venice
Must needes giue ſentence 'gainst the Merchant there.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shy.
SPEECH.LINE: My deeds vpon my head, I craue the Law,
The penaltie and forfeite of my bond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Is he not able to discharge the money?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bas.
SPEECH.LINE: Yes, heere I tender it for him in the Court,
Yea, twice the ſumme, if that will not ſuffice,
I will be bound to pay it ten times ore,
On forfeit of my hands, my head, my heart:
If this will not ſuffice, it must appeare
That malice beares downe truth. And I beseech you
Wrest once the Law to your authority.
To do a great right, do a little wrong,
And curbe this cruell diuell of his will.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: It must not be, there is no power in Venice
Can alter a decree established:
'Twill be recorded for a President,
And many an error by the ſame example,
Will rush into the ſtate: It cannot be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: A Daniel come to iudgement, yea a Daniel.
O wise young Iudge, how do I honour thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you let me looke vpon the bond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere ‘tis mo’t reuerend Doctor, heere it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Shylocke, there's thrice thy monie offered thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shy.
SPEECH.LINE: An oath, an oath, I haue an oath in heauen:
Shall I lay periurie vpon my ſoule?
No not for Venice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Why this bond is forfeit,
And lawfully by this the Iew may claime
A pound of flesh, to be by him cut off
Neerest the Merchants heart; be mercifull,
Take thrice thy money, bid me teare the bond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: When it is paid according to the tenure.
It doth appeare you are a worthy Iudge:
You know the Law, your exposition
Hath beene mo’t ſound. I charge you by the Law,
Whereof you are a well-deseruing pillar,
Proceede to iudgement: By my ſoule I ſweare,
There is no power in the tongue of man
To alter me: I ſtay heere on my bond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t heartily I do beseech the Court
To giue the iudgement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then thus it is:
You must prepare your bosome for his knife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: O noble Iudge, O excellent yong man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: For the intent and purpose of the Law
Hath full relation to the penaltie,
Which heere appeareth due vpon the bond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis verie true: O wise and vpright Iudge,
How much more elder art thou then thy lookes?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore lay bare your bosome.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: I, his brest,
So ſayes the bond, doth it not noble Iudge?
Neerest his heart, those are the very words.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: It is ſo: Are there ballance heere to weigh the flesh?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue them ready.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Haue by ſome Surgeon Shylock on your charge
To ſtop his wounds, least he ſhould bleede to death.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: It is not nominated in the bond?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: It is not ſo exprest: but what of that?
'Twere good you do ſo much for charitie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: I cannot finde it, ‘tis not in the bond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Come Merchant, haue you any thing to ſay?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: But little: I am arm’d and well prepar’d.
Giue me your hand Baſſanio, fare you well.
Greeue not that I am falne to this for you:
For heerein fortune ſhewes her ſelfe more kinde
Then is her custome. It is ſtill her vse
To let the wretched man out-liue his wealth,
To view with hollow eye, and wrinkled brow
An age of pouerty. From which lingring penance
Of ſuch miserie, doth ſhe cut me off:
Commend me to your honourable Wife,
Tell her the proceſſe of Anthonio's end:
Say how I lou’d you; ſpeake me faire in death:
And when the tale is told, bid her be iudge,
Whether Baſſanio had not once a Loue:
Repent not you that you ſhall loose your friend,
And he repents not that he payes your debt.
For if the Iew do cut but deepe enough,
Ile pay it instantly, with all my heart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bas.
SPEECH.LINE: Anthonio, I am married to a wife,
Which is as deere to me as life it ſelfe,
But life it ſelfe, my wife, and all the world,
Are not with me esteem’d aboue thy life.
I would loose all, I ſacrifice them all
Heere to this deuill, to deliuer you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Your wife would giue you little thanks for that
If ſhe were by to heare you make the offer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue a wife whom I protest I loue,
I would ſhe were in heauen, ſo ſhe could
Intreat ſome power to change this currish Iew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ner.
SPEECH.LINE: ‘Tis well you offer it behinde her backe,
The wish would make else an vnquiet house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: These be the Christian husbands: I haue a daughter
Would any of the ſtocke of Barrabas
Had beene her husband, rather then a Christian.
We trifle time, I pray thee pursue ſentence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: A pound of that ſame marchants flesh is thine,
The Court awards it, and the law doth giue it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t rightfull Iudge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: And you must cut this flesh from off his breast,
The Law allowes it, and the Court awards it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t learned Iudge, a ſentence, come prepare.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Tarry a little, there is ſomething else,
This bond doth giue thee heere no iot of bloud,
The words expresly are a pound of flesh:
Then take thy bond, take thou thy pound of flesh,
But in the cutting it, if thou dost ſhed
One drop of Christian bloud, thy lands and goods
Are by the Lawes of Venice confiscate
Vnto the ſtate of Venice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: O vpright Iudge,
Marke Iew, o learned Iudge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shy.
SPEECH.LINE: Is that the law?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Thy ſelfe ſhalt ſee the Act:
For as thou vrgest iustice, be aſſur’d
Thou ſhalt haue iustice more then thou desirest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: O learned Iudge, mark Iew, a learned Iudge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Iew.
SPEECH.LINE: I take this offer then, pay the bond thrice,
And let the Christian goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere is the money.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Soft, the Iew ſhall haue all iustice, ſoft, no haste,
He ſhall haue nothing but the penalty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: O Iew, an vpright Iudge, a learned Iudge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Therefore prepare thee to cut off the flesh,
Shed thou no bloud, nor cut thou leſſe nor more
But iust a pound of flesh: if thou tak'st more
Or leſſe then a iust pound, be it ſo much
As makes it light or heauy in the ſubstance,
Or the deuision of the twentieth part
Of one poore ſcruple, nay if the ſcale doe turne
But in the estimation of a hayre,
Thou diest, and all thy goods are confiscate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: A ſecond Daniel, a Daniel Iew,
Now infidell I haue thee on the hip.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Why doth the Iew pause, take thy forfeiture.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shy.
SPEECH.LINE: Giue me my principall, and let me goe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I haue it ready for thee, heere it is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: He hath refus’d it in the open Court,
He ſhall haue meerly iustice and his bond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: A Daniel ſtill ſay I, a ſecond Daniel,
I thanke thee Iew for teaching me that word.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shy.
SPEECH.LINE: Shall I not haue barely my principall?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou ſhalt haue nothing but the forfeiture,
To be taken ſo at thy perill Iew.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shy.
SPEECH.LINE: Why then the Deuill giue him good of it:
Ile ſtay no longer question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Tarry Iew,
The Law hath yet another hold on you.
It is enacted in the Lawes of Venice,
If it be proued against an Alien,
That by direct, or indirect attempts
He ſeeke the life of any Citizen,
The party gainst the which he doth contriue,
Shall ſeaze one halfe his goods, the other halfe
Comes to the priuie coffer of the State,
And the offenders life lies in the mercy
Of the Duke onely, gainst all other voice.
In which predicament I ſay thou ſtandst:
For it appeares by manifest proceeding,
That indirectly, and directly to,
Thou hast contriu’d against the very life
Of the defendant: and thou hast incur’d
The danger formerly by me rehearst.
Downe therefore, and beg mercy of the Duke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: Beg that thou maist haue leaue to hang thy ſelfe,
And yet thy wealth being forfeit to the ſtate,
Thou hast not left the value of a cord,
Therefore thou must be hang’d at the ſtates charge.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: That thou ſhalt ſee the difference of our ſpirit,
I pardon thee thy life before thou aske it:
For halfe thy wealth, it is Anthonio's
The other halfe comes to the generall ſtate,
Which humbleneſſe may driue vnto a fine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: I for the ſtate, not for Anthonio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shy.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, take my life and all, pardon not that,
You take my house, when you do take the prop
That doth ſustaine my house: you take my life
When you doe take the meanes whereby I liue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: What mercy can you render him Anthonio?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: A halter gratis, nothing else for Gods ſake.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: So please my Lord the Duke, and all the Court
To quit the fine for one halfe of his goods,
I am content: ſo he will let me haue
The other halfe in vse, to render it
Vpon his death, vnto the Gentleman
That lately ſtole his daughter.
Two things prouided more, that for this fauour
He presently become a Christian:
The other, that he doe record a gift
Heere in the Court of all he dies poſſest
Vnto his ſonne Lorenzo, and his daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: He ſhall doe this, or else I doe recant
The pardon that I late pronounced heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Art thou contented Iew? what dost thou ſay?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shy.
SPEECH.LINE: I am content.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Clarke, draw a deed of gift.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Shy.
SPEECH.LINE: I pray you giue me leaue to goe from hence,
I am not well, ſend the deed after me,
And I will ſigne it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duke.
SPEECH.LINE: Get thee gone, but doe it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: In christning thou ſhalt haue two godfathers,
Had I been iudge, thou ſhouldst haue had ten more,
To bring thee to the gallowes, not to the font.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Du.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir I intreat you with me home to dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: I humbly doe desire your Grace of pardon,
I must away this night toward Padua,
And it is meete I presently ſet forth.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Duk.
SPEECH.LINE: I am ſorry that your leysure ſerues you not:
Anthonio, gratifie this gentleman,
For in my minde you are much bound to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Mo’t worthy gentleman, I and my friend
Haue by your wisedome beene this day acquitted
Of greeuous penalties, in lieu whereof,
Three thousand Ducats due vnto the Iew
We freely cope your curteous paines withall.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: And ſtand indebted ouer and aboue
In loue and ſeruice to you euermore.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: He is well paid that is well ſatisfied,
And I deliuering you, am ſatisfied,
And therein doe account my ſelfe well paid,
My minde was neuer yet more mercinarie.
I pray you know me when we meete againe,
I wish you well, and ſo I take my leaue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Deare ſir, of force I must attempt you further,
Take ſome remembrance of vs as a tribute,
Not as fee: grant me two things, I pray you
Not to denie me, and to pardon me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: You preſſe mee farre, and therefore I will yeeld,
Giue me your gloues, Ile weare them for your ſake,
And for your loue Ile take this ring from you,
Doe not draw backe your hand, ile take no more,
And you in loue ſhall not deny me this?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: This ring good ſir, alas it is a trifle,
I will not ſhame my ſelfe to giue you this.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: I wil haue nothing else but onely this,
And now methinkes I haue a minde to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bas.
SPEECH.LINE: There's more depends on this then on the valew,
The dearest ring in Venice will I giue you,
And finde it out by proclamation,
Onely for this I pray you pardon me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: I ſee ſir you are liberall in offers,
You taught me first to beg, and now me thinkes
You teach me how a beggar ſhould be anſwer’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bas.
SPEECH.LINE: Good ſir, this ring was giuen me by my wife,
And when ſhe put it on, ſhe made me vow
That I ſhould neither ſell, nor giue, nor lose it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: That ſcuse ſerues many men to ſaue their gifts,
And if your wife be not a mad woman,
And know how well I haue deseru’d this ring,
Shee would not hold out enemy for euer
For giuing it to me: well, peace be with you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: My L[ord]. Baſſanio, let him haue the ring,
Let his deseruings and my loue withall
Be valued against your wiues commandement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Goe Gratiano, run and ouer-take him,
Giue him the ring, and bring him if thou canst
Vnto Anthonios house, away, make haste.
Come, you and I will thither presently,
And in the morning early will we both
Flie toward Belmont, come Anthonio.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Enquire the Iewes house out, giue him this deed,
And let him ſigne it, wee'll away to night,
And be a day before our husbands home:
This deed will be well welcome to Lorenzo.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire ſir, you are well ore-tane:
My L[ord]. Baſſanio vpon more aduice,
Hath ſent you heere this ring, and doth intreat
Your company at dinner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: That cannot be;
His ring I doe accept mo’t thankfully,
And ſo I pray you tell him: furthermore,
I pray you ſhew my youth old Shylockes house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: That will I doe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ner.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, I would ſpeake with you:
Ile ſee if I can get my husbands ring
Which I did make him ſweare to keepe for euer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Thou maist I warrant, we ſhal haue old ſwearing
That they did giue the rings away to men;
But weele out-face them, and out-sweare them to:
Away, make haste, thou know'st where I will tarry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ner.
SPEECH.LINE: Come good ſir, will you ſhew me to this house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: The moone ſhines bright. In ſuch a night as this,
When the ſweet winde did gently kiſſe the trees,
And they did make no noyse, in ſuch a night
Troylus me thinkes mounted the Troian walls,
And ſigh’d his ſoule toward the Grecian tents
Where Creſſed lay that night.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ies.
SPEECH.LINE: In ſuch a night
Did Thisbie fearefully ore-trip the dewe,
And ſaw the Lyons ſhadow ere himselfe,
And ranne dismayed away.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: In ſuch a night
Stood Dido with a Willow in her hand
Vpon the wilde ſea bankes, and waft her Loue
To come againe to Carthage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ies.
SPEECH.LINE: In ſuch a night
Medea gathered the inchanted hearbs
That did renew old Eson.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: In ſuch a night
Did Ieſſica ſteale from the wealthy Iewe,
And with an Vnthrift Loue did runne from Venice,
As farre as Belmont.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ies.
SPEECH.LINE: In ſuch a night
Did young Lorenzo ſweare he lou’d her well,
Stealing her ſoule with many vowes of faith,
And nere a true one.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: In ſuch a night
Did pretty Ieſſica (like a little ſhrow)
Slander her Loue, and he forgaue it her.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ieſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: I would out-night you did no body come:
But harke, I heare the footing of a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: Who comes ſo fast in ſilence of the night?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: A friend.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: A friend, what friend? your name I pray you friend?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: Stephano is my name, and I bring word
My Mistreſſe will before the breake of day
Be heere at Belmont, ſhe doth ſtray about
By holy croſſes where ſhe kneeles and prayes
For happy wedlocke houres.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: Who comes with her?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mes.
SPEECH.LINE: None but a holy Hermit and her maid:
I pray you is my Master yet return’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: He is not, nor we haue not heard from him,
But goe we in I pray thee Ieſſica,
And ceremoniously let vs prepare
Some welcome for the Mistreſſe of the house,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Sola, ſola: wo ha ho, ſola, ſola.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: Who calls?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Sola, did you ſee M[aster]. Lorenzo, & M[aster]. Lorenzo, ſola,

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: Leaue hollowing man, heere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Sola, where, where?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Clo.
SPEECH.LINE: Tel him ther's a Post come from my Master, with his horne full of good newes, my Master will be here ere morning ſweete ſoule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: Let's in, and there expect their comming.
And yet no matter: why ſhould we goe in?
My friend Stephen, ſignifie pray you
Within the house, your Mistreſſe is at hand,
And bring your musique foorth into the ayre.
How ſweet the moone-light ſleepes vpon this banke,
Heere will we ſit, and let the ſounds of musicke
Creepe in our eares ſoft ſtilnes, and the night
Become the tutches of ſweet harmonie:
Sit Ieſſica, looke how the floore of heauen
Is thicke inlayed with pattens of bright gold,
There's not the ſmallest orbe which thou beholdst
But in his motion like an Angell ſings,
Still quiring to the young eyed Cherubins;
Such harmonie is in immortall ſoules,
But whilst this muddy vesture of decay
Doth grosly close in it, we cannot heare it:
Come hœ, and wake Diana with a hymne,
With ſweetest tutches pearce your Mistreſſe eare,
And draw her home with musicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ieſſi.
SPEECH.LINE: I am neuer merry when I heare ſweet musique.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: The reason is, your ſpirits are attentiue:
For doe but note a wilde and wanton heard
Or race of youthful and vnhandled colts,
Fetching mad bounds, bellowing and neighing loud,
Which is the hot condition of their bloud,
If they but heare perchance a trumpet ſound,
Or any ayre of musicke touch their eares,
You ſhall perceiue them make a mutuall ſtand,
Their ſauage eyes turn’d to a modest gaze,
By the ſweet power of musicke: therefore the Pœt
Did faine that Orpheus drew trees, ſtones, and floods.
Since naught ſo ſtockish, hard, and full of rage,
But musicke for time doth change his nature,
The man that hath no musicke in himselfe,
Nor is not moued with concord of ſweet ſounds,
Is fit for treasons, ſtratagems, and ſpoyles,
The motions of his ſpirit are dull as night,
And his affections darke as Erobus,
Let no ſuch man be trusted: marke the musicke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: That light we ſee is burning in my hall:
How farre that little candell throwes his beames,
So ſhines a good deed in a naughty world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ner.
SPEECH.LINE: When the moone ſhone we did not ſee the candle?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: So doth the greater glory dim the leſſe,
A ſubstitute ſhines brightly as a King
Vntill a King be by, and then his ſtate
Empties it ſelfe, as doth an inland brooke
Into the maine of waters: musique, harke.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ner.
SPEECH.LINE: It is your musicke Madame of the house.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Nothing is good I ſee without respect,
Methinkes it ſounds much ſweeter then by day?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ner.
SPEECH.LINE: Silence bestowes that vertue on it Madam.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: The Crow doth ſing as ſweetly as the Larke
When neither is attended: and I thinke
The Nightingale if ſhe ſhould ſing by day
When euery Goose is cackling, would be thought
No better a Musitian then the Wren?
How many things by ſeason, ſeason’d are
To their right praise, and true perfection:
Peace, how the Moone ſleepes with Endimion,
And would not be awak’d.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: That is the voice,
Or I am much deceiu’d of Portia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: He knowes me as the blinde man knowes the
Cuckow by the bad voice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: Deere Lady welcome home?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: We haue bene praying for our husbands welfare
Which ſpeed we hope the better for our words,
Are they return’d?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: Madam, they are not yet:
But there is come a Meſſenger before
To ſignifie their comming.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Go in Nerriſſa,
Giue order to my ſeruants, that they take
No note at all of our being absent hence,
Nor you Lorenzo, Ieſſica nor you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lor.
SPEECH.LINE: Your husband is at hand, I heare his Trumpet,
We are no tell-tales Madam, feare you not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: This night methinkes is but the daylight ſicke,
It lookes a little paler, ‘tis a day,
Such as the day is, when the Sun is hid.

SCENE.STAGEDIR: Enter Baſſanio, Anthonio, Gratiano, and their Followers

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bas.
SPEECH.LINE: We ſhould hold day with the Antipodes,
If you would walke in absence of the ſunne.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Let me giue light, but let me not be light,
For a light wife doth make a heauie husband,
And neuer be Baſſanio ſo for me,
But God ſort all: you are welcome home my Lord.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: I thanke you Madam, giue welcom to my friend
This is the man, this is Anthonio,
To whom I am ſo infinitely bound.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: You ſhould in all ſence be much bound to him,
For as I heare he was much bound for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: No more then I am wel acquitted of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, you are verie welcome to our house:
It must appeare in other waies then words,
Therefore I ſcant this breathing curtesie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: By yonder Moone I ſweare you do me wrong,
Infaith I gaue it to the Iudges Clearke,
Would he were gelt that had it for my part,
Since you do take it Loue ſo much at hart.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: A quarrel hœ alreadie, what’s the matter?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: About a hoope of Gold, a paltry Ring
That ſhe did giue me, whose Pœsie was
For all the world like Cutlers Pœtry
Vpon a knife; Loue mee, and leaue mee not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ner.
SPEECH.LINE: What talke you of the Pœsie or the valew:
You ſwore to me when I did giue it you,
That you would weare it til the houre of death,
And that it ſhould lye with you in your graue,
Though not for me, yet for your vehement oaths,
You ſhould haue beene respectiue and haue kept it.
Gaue it a Iudges Clearke: but wel I know
The Clearke wil nere weare haire on's face that had it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: He wil, and if he liue to be a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nerriſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: I, if a Woman liue to be a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: Now by this hand I gaue it to a youth,
A kinde of boy, a little ſcrubbed boy,
No higher then thy ſelfe, the Iudges Clearke,
A prating boy that begg’d it as a Fee,
I could not for my heart deny it him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: You were too blame, I must be plaine with you,
To part ſo ſlightly with your wiues first gift,
A thing ſtucke on with oathes vpon your finger,
And ſo riueted with faith vnto your flesh.
I gaue my Loue a Ring, and made him ſweare
Neuer to part with it, and heere he ſtands:
I dare be ſworne for him, he would not leaue it,
Nor plucke it from his finger, for the wealth
That the world masters. Now in faith Gratiano,
You giue your wife too vnkinde a cause of greefe,
And 'twere to me I ſhould be mad at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Why I were best to cut my left hand off,
And ſweare I lost the Ring defending it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: My Lord Baſſanio gaue his Ring away
Vnto the Iudge that beg’d it, and indeede
Deseru’d it too: and then the Boy his Clearke
That tooke ſome paines in writing, he begg’d mine,
And neyther man nor master would take ought
But the two Rings.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: What Ring gaue you my Lord?
Not that I hope which you receiu’d of me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: If I could adde a lie vnto a fault,
I would deny it: but you ſee my finger
Hath not the Ring vpon it, it is gone.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Euen ſo voide is your false heart of truth.
By heauen I wil nere come in your bed
Vntil I ſee the Ring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ner.
SPEECH.LINE: Nor I in yours, til I againe ſee mine.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Sweet Portia,
If you did know to whom I gaue the Ring,
If you did know for whom I gaue the Ring,
And would conceiue for what I gaue the Ring,
And how vnwillingly I left the Ring,
When nought would be accepted but the Ring,
You would abate the ſtrength of your displeasure?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: If you had knowne the vertue of the Ring,
Or halfe her worthineſſe that gaue the Ring,
Or your owne honour to containe the Ring,
You would not then haue parted with the Ring:
What man is there ſo much vnreasonable,
If you had pleas’d to haue defended it
With any termes of Zeale: wanted the modestie
To vrge the thing held as a ceremonie:
Nerriſſa teaches me what to beleeue,
Ile die for't, but ſome Woman had the Ring?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: No by mine honor Madam, by my ſoule
No Woman had it, but a ciuill Doctor,
Which did refuse three thousand Ducates of me,
And beg’d the Ring; the which I did denie him,
And ſuffer’d him to go displeas’d away:
Euen he that had held vp the verie life
Of my deere friend. What ſhould I ſay ſweete Lady?
I was inforc’d to ſend it after him,
I was beset with ſhame and curtesie,
My honor would not let ingratitude
So much besmeare it. Pardon me good Lady,
And by these bleſſed Candles of the night,
Had you bene there, I thinke you would haue beg’d
The Ring of me, to giue the worthie Doctor?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Let not that Doctor ere come neere my house,
Since he hath got the iewell that I loued,
And that which you did ſweare to keepe for me,
I will become as liberall as you,
Ile not deny him any thing I haue,
No, not my body, nor my husbands bed:
Know him I ſhall, I am well ſure of it.
Lie not a night from home. Watch me like Argos,
If you doe not, if I be left alone,
Now by mine honour which is yet mine owne,
Ile haue the Doctor for my bedfellow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nerriſſa.
SPEECH.LINE: And I his Clarke: therefore be well aduis’d
How you doe leaue me to mine owne protection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: Well, doe you ſo: let not me take him then,
For if I doe, ile mar the yong Clarks pen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: I am th’ vnhappy ſubiect of these quarrels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Sir, grieue not you,
You are welcome notwithstanding.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bas.
SPEECH.LINE: Portia, forgiue me this enforced wrong,
And in the hearing of these manie friends
I ſweare to thee, euen by thine owne faire eyes
Wherein I ſee my ſelfe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Marke you but that?
In both my eyes he doubly ſees himselfe:
In each eye one, ſweare by your double ſelfe,
And there's an oath of credit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bas.
SPEECH.LINE: Nay, but heare me.
Pardon this fault, and by my ſoule I ſweare
I neuer more will breake an oath with thee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anth.
SPEECH.LINE: I once did lend my bodie for thy wealth,
Which but for him that had your husbands ring
Had quite miscarried. I dare be bound againe,
My ſoule vpon the forfeit, that your Lord
Will neuer more breake faith aduisedlie.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Then you ſhall be his ſuretie: giue him this,
And bid him keepe it better then the other.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ant.
SPEECH.LINE: Heere Lord Baſſanio, ſwear to keep this ring.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: By heauen it is the ſame I gaue the Doctor.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: I had it of him: pardon Baſſanio,
For by this ring the Doctor lay with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ner.
SPEECH.LINE: And pardon me my gentle Gratiano,
For that ſame ſcrubbed boy the Doctors Clarke
In liew of this, last night did lye with me.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: Why this is like the mending of high waies
In Sommer, where the waies are faire enough:
What, are we Cuckolds ere we haue deseru’d it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: Speake not ſo groſſely, you are all amaz’d;
Heere is a letter, reade it at your leysure,
It comes from Padua from Bellario,
There you ſhall finde that Portia was the Doctor,
Nerriſſa there her Clarke. Lorenzo heere
Shall witneſſe I ſet forth as ſoone as you,
And but eu'n now return’d: I haue not yet
Entred my house. Anthonio you are welcome,
And I haue better newes in ſtore for you
Then you expect: vnseale this letter ſoone,
There you ſhall finde three of your Argosies
Are richly come to harbour ſodainlie.
You ſhall not know by what ſtrange accident
I chanced on this letter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Antho.
SPEECH.LINE: I am dumbe.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: Were you the Doctor, and I knew you not?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: Were you the Clark that is to make me cuckold.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ner.
SPEECH.LINE: I, but the Clark that neuer meanes to doe it,
Vnleſſe he liue vntill he be a man.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baſſ.
SPEECH.LINE: (Sweet Doctor) you ſhall be my bedfellow,
When I am absent, then lie with my wife.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: An.
SPEECH.LINE: (Sweet Ladie) you haue giuen me life & liuing;
For heere I reade for certaine that my ſhips
Are ſafelie come to Rode.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: How now Lorenzo?
My Clarke hath ſome good comforts to for you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ner.
SPEECH.LINE: I, and Ile giue them him without a fee.
There doe I giue to you and Ieſſica
From the rich Iewe, a ſpeciall deed of gift
After his death, of all he dies poſſeſſ’d of.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Loren.
SPEECH.LINE: Faire Ladies you drop Manna in the way
Of ſtarued people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Por.
SPEECH.LINE: It is almost morning,
And yet I am ſure you are not ſatisfied
Of these euents at full. Let vs goe in,
And charge vs there vpon intergatories,
And we will anſwer all things faithfully.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gra.
SPEECH.LINE: Let it be ſo, the first intergatory
That my Nerriſſa ſhall be ſworne on, is,
Whether till the next night ſhe had rather ſtay,
Or goe to bed, now being two houres to day,
But were the day come, I ſhould wish it darke,
Till I were couching with the Doctors Clarke.
Well, while I liue, Ile feare no other thing
So ſore, as keeping ſafe Nerriſſas ring.
